raw_text:
Text message record smashed
 
 UK mobile owners continue to break records with their text messaging, with latest figures showing that 26 billion texts were sent in total in 2004.
 
 The figures collected by the Mobile Data Association (MDA) showed that 2.4 billion were fired off in December alone, the highest monthly total ever. That was 26% more than in December 2003. The records even surpassed the MDA's own predictions, it said. Every day 78 million messages are sent and there are no signs of a slow down. Before December's bumper text record, the previous highest monthly total was in October 2004, when 2.3 billion were sent. Text messaging is set to smash more records in 2005 too, said the MDA, with forecasts suggesting a total of 30 billion for the year.
 
 Even though mobiles are becoming increasingly sophisticated with much more multimedia applications, texting is still one of the most useful functions of mobiles. People are using SMS to do much more too. Booking cinema tickets, text voting, and news or sports text alerts are growing popular. Mobile owners have also given the chance to donate to the Disasters Emergency Committee's (DEC) Asian Tsunami fund by texting "Donate" to a simple short code number. Looking further ahead in the year, the MDA's chairman Mike Short, has predicted that more people will go online through their mobiles, estimating 15 billion WAP page impressions. Handsets with GPRS capability - an "always on" net connection - will rise to 75%, while 3G mobile ownership growing to five million by the end of 2005. These third generation mobiles offer a high-speed connection which means more data like video can be received on the phone. Globally, mobile phone sales passed 167 million in the third quarter of 2004, according to a recent report from analysts Gartner. That was 26% more than the previous year. It is predicted that there would be two billion handsets in use worldwide by the end of 2005.
llama3.2:1b: UK mobile owners sent over 26 billion texts in 2004 and had a monthly total of 2.4 billion, surpassing expectations set by the Mobile Data Association (MDA). This was followed by December's record-breaking month with 78 million messages sent, making it 26% higher than the previous year. The MDA also predicts that mobile phone sales will continue to rise, with over 167 million units sold in the third quarter of 2004 and an estimated two billion handsets in use worldwide by the end of 2005, accompanied by increased data speeds due to the adoption of third-generation (3G) mobile networks.
llama3.2:3b: UK mobile owners sent 2.4 billion texts in December 2004, a record high. The total for the year is forecasted to be around 30 billion. Mobile phone sales rose 26% to 167 million in the third quarter of 2004 and global sales are predicted to reach two billion by the end of 2005.
gemma2:2b: In 2004, UK mobile users sent 26 billion texts, a new record high driven by increased monthly usage and diverse applications like booking tickets, voting, and news alerts.  Text messaging is expected to continue this trend in 2005 with predictions of 30 billion messages. Mobile technology is also advancing rapidly, with GPRS becoming more common and 3G adoption growing. The global mobile phone market has been booming as well, with sales exceeding 167 million units in the third quarter of 2004.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UK mobile users have broken records with text messaging: The latest figures show that 26 billion texts were sent, surpassing MDA's own predictions and marking a record-breaking total for the year. Mobiles are increasingly sophisticated with multimedia applications and texting remains one of the most useful functions. Some people use text messaging to book cinema tickets, vote on news alerts or text "Donate" from a simple short code number. Handsets with GPRS capability will be available in 2005 and mobile phone sales passed 167 million by end 2004.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Text messaging usage continues to rise rapidly, reaching 30 billion messages sent annually as of 2004 and set to surpass this figure in 2005. Mobile phones are becoming more sophisticated with multimedia capabilities expanding their usefulness beyond basic calling functions. Donation via text is popular for charitable causes, and mobile internet access through GPRS and 3G technology is expected to increase significantly.
qwen2.5:3b: UK mobile owners sent 26 billion texts in total in 2004, with December's volume hitting a record 2.4 billion (up 26% from December 2003). Texting is on track to break more records in 2005 with forecasts of 30 billion messages. Despite sophisticated multimedia applications, texting remains popular for functions like booking cinema tickets and receiving news alerts. Mobiles are expected to grow in sophistication, with handsets having GPRS capability rising to 75% by end-2005 and 3G ownership reaching five million. Globally, mobile phone sales increased 26% year-over-year in the third quarter of 2004, reaching over 167 million units.
opencoder:1.5b: The text message record has been manipulated or altered to make it appear as though it's attempting to convey a summary of the key points and details presented within the original statement. However, it was important to retain the main ideas or points of the original text in its summarized form.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should include:

1. The text message record smashed, which means the total number of texts sent in a month was higher than expected.
2. The UK mobile owners continue to break records with their text messaging, with latest figures showing that 26 billion texts were sent in total in 2004.
3. Every day 78 million messages are sent and there are no signs of a slow down. Before December's bumper text record, the previous highest monthly total was in October 2004, when 2.3 billion were sent. Text messaging is set to smash more records in 2005 too, said the MDA, with forecasts suggesting a total of 30 billion for the year.
4. Even though mobiles are becoming increasingly sophisticated with much more multimedia applications, texting is still one of the most useful functions of mobiles. People are using SMS to do much more than before. Booking cinema tickets, text voting, and news or sports text alerts are growing popular. Mobile owners have also given the chance to donate to the Disasters Emergency Committee's (DEC) Asian Tsunami fund by texting "Donate" to a simple short code number. Looking further ahead in the year, the MDA's chairman Mike Short, has predicted that more people will go online through their mobiles, estimating 15 billion WAP page impressions. Handsets with GPRS capability - an "always on" net connection - will rise to 75%, while 3G mobile ownership growing to five million by the end of 2005. These third generation mobiles offer a high-speed connection which means more data like video can be received on the phone. Globally, mobile phone sales passed 167 million in the third quarter of 2004, according to a recent report from analysts Gartner. That was 26% more than the previous year. It is predicted that there would be two billion handsets in use worldwide by the end of 2005.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize the provided text about mobile data usage and predictions made by the Mobile Data Association. The user wants only the summary in plain text without any explanations or formatting.

First, let me read through the text carefully. It talks about how UK mobile owners are breaking records with text messaging, especially in 2004. There were figures like 26 billion texts and some significant monthly growth from December onwards. The MDA's predictions had the highest monthly total, so they even surpassed their own estimates.

Next, it mentions that despite increasing sophistication of mobile applications, texting remains vital for users. People use SMS for things like booking tickets, voting, and news. Mobile owners also donated to a disaster fund using text messages.

The summary should include the key points: 2004's high text usage records, the MDA's performance, growth predictions for 2005, and trends with GPRS and 3G networks.

I'll need to make sure each main point is clearly captured without too much detail. I should avoid any explanations or extra words beyond what's necessary.
</think>

26 billion texts were sent in 2004 by UK mobile owners, the highest monthly total ever. The Mobile Data Association (MDA) reported a December figure of 2.4 billion texts, up by 26% from 2003. Mobile data usage grew daily at 78 million messages and is set to surpass records in 2005 with forecasts for 30 billion texts the year. Texting remains essential for users, like booking cinema tickets or news alerts. MDA chairman Mike Short predicted mobile ownership growth, with GPRS networks reaching 75% and 3G growing by five million. Third-generation handsets sold 167 million units in Q4 2004, a 26% increase from the previous year. Globally, global sales reached 167 million units by end-2005.
tinyllama:1.1b: United Kingdom mobile owners continue to break records with their text messaging, collecting over 26 billion messages per month in 2004 alone. This was a 26% increase from the previous year's total. The most recent MDAs' predictions show that an additional 30 billion messages are expected in 2005, with a forecasted total of 167 million mobile phones sold globally by the end of the year. Text messaging is set to continue becoming more useful and popular, with applications such as booking cinema tickets, voting online, and news/sports text alerts gaining popularity. The Disasters Emergency Committee's Asian Tsunami fund via SMS donation has also gained traction among mobile phone users in the UK, as has WAP (web application protocol) page impression growth by handsets with GPRS (global platform for real-time services) capability. Over 15 billion text messages are expected to go online through WAP by year's end, with an estimated five million phones now equipped with the high-speed connection technology.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The text message record has surpassed last month’s figures, with over 26 billion messages sent in December alone. This demonstrates the increasing popularity and usefulness of mobile texting, as more people are turning to their phones for information and entertainment. Mobile owners continue to break records by sending a total of 2.4 billion messages in December, making it the highest monthly total ever recorded. The MDA expects that 15 billion WAP page impressions will be generated by mobile users in 2005, with the average user expected to send about 80 messages per day. This growth is largely due to the increasing use of SMS for donating to disaster relief efforts and voting during elections. Future trends predict that there will be more people using their mobiles for online activities through their WAP phones, which have GPRS capabilities, allowing them to receive high-speed internet connections. Overall, mobile phone sales are expected to pass 167 million by the end of 2005, with global handset sales reaching two billion units by the end of this year.
phi:2.7b: In 2004, a total of 26 billion text messages were sent globally, breaking records set in 2003 and with no signs of slowing down. Mobile users are using SMS for tasks such as booking tickets, voting, and receiving alerts. The MDA predicts that texting will continue to be a useful function while new multimedia applications become more sophisticated. Handsets with GPRS capability are gaining popularity, with more people going online through their mobiles. The report by Gartner predicts that there will be two billion handsets in use worldwide by the end of 2005. Mobile phone sales reached 167 million in the third quarter of
orca-mini:3b: The text message record has been broken with UK mobile owners sending a total of 26 billion texts in 2004, with December's figures being the highest monthly total ever at 2.4 billion. This is an increase of 26% from the previous year. Mobile users are also using SMS for more purposes such as booking cinema tickets, text voting, and news or sports text alerts. In response to the Asian Tsunami disaster, people were able to donate to the DEC's fund through texting a simple short code number. Looking further ahead in the year, the MDA predicts that mobile ownership of 3G handsets will increase to five million by the end of 2005 while global mobile phone sales passed 167 million in the third quarter of 2004, an increase of 26%. Two billion handsets are expected to be in use worldwide by the end of 2005.
hermes3:3b: Text messaging records broken; 26B texts sent in 2004, increasing monthly totals.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: UK mobile users sent 26 billion texts in 2004, with 2.4 billion sent in December alone, surpassing records set before. The Mobile Data Association predicts text messaging will break more records in 2005, reaching 30 billion for the year. SMS is becoming increasingly versatile, allowing for booking cinema tickets, voting via text, and receiving news or sports alerts. Furthermore, 75% of handsets with GPRS capability are expected by the end of 2005, leading to high-speed connections enabling more data reception, such as video. The Mobile Data Association (MDA) expects texting to continue growing, predicting 30 billion messages in 2005. Despite advances in mobile technology, SMS remains widely used for various services, including ticket booking, voting, and charity donations. The MDA also forecasts increased mobile internet usage, with 15 billion WAP page impressions and a rise in GPRS and 3G handset adoption. Global mobile phone sales reached 167 million in Q3 2004, with projections of two billion handsets in use worldwide by the end of 2005.
stablelm2:1.6b: The text discusses how UK mobile owners are sending over one billion texts each month, with December seeing an unprecedented 2.4 billion sent - this surpasses even the MDA's own predictions. Text messaging is set to continue breaking records in 2025, as it becomes increasingly common for people to use SMS for various purposes like booking cinema tickets and voting. Globally, there were over 1 billion mobile phone users in Q4 2024.
granite3.1-dense:2b: In 2004, UK mobile users sent a record-breaking 26 billion texts, with December's 2.4 billion messages being the highest monthly total ever, a 26% increase from December 2003. This trend continues in 2005, with forecasts predicting 30 billion texts for the year. Despite mobiles' multimedia advancements, texting remains a crucial feature for various purposes like booking, voting, and receiving alerts. SMS is also used for charitable donations to the DEC's Asian Tsunami fund. The MDA anticipates 15 billion WAP page impressions in 2005, with GPRS capability reaching 75% and 3G mobiles increasing to five million by year-end, offering high-speed data for video content. Globally, mobile phone sales grew 26% annually from the previous year, surpassing 167 million in Q3 2004, with two billion expected worldwide by the end of 2005.
reference: Before December's bumper text record, the previous highest monthly total was in October 2004, when 2.3 billion were sent.UK mobile owners continue to break records with their text messaging, with latest figures showing that 26 billion texts were sent in total in 2004.Text messaging is set to smash more records in 2005 too, said the MDA, with forecasts suggesting a total of 30 billion for the year.The figures collected by the Mobile Data Association (MDA) showed that 2.4 billion were fired off in December alone, the highest monthly total ever.Looking further ahead in the year, the MDA's chairman Mike Short, has predicted that more people will go online through their mobiles, estimating 15 billion WAP page impressions.That was 26% more than the previous year.Handsets with GPRS capability - an "always on" net connection - will rise to 75%, while 3G mobile ownership growing to five million by the end of 2005.
